subject: Psychology
statement_full_text: Working at my mother's language school shaped the way I first encountered child development. In my time there, I witnessed in real-time the children's growth and changes, in such a distinct environment to accommodate different learning needs best. With some of the children being disabled, neurodiverse, or otherwise "different" from others, this sparked my lasting curiosity to understand the difference: Why do some children seem to struggle with communication or routine, while others formed friendships or grasped language concepts at different paces? And in some cases, what makes these children faster learners than their peers, despite additional challenges? These questions led me to search for answers in my own time, looking towards developmental psychology for a better understanding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Working at my mother's language school shaped the way I first encountered child development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The opening sentence is vague and doesn't clearly communicate what specific aspect of child development sparked your interest. The phrasing 'shaped the way I first encountered' is unnecessarily complex.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start more directly with what you observed and why it mattered. Be specific about what you witnessed that sparked your curiosity.

feedback_items.weak_passage: in such a distinct environment to accommodate different learning needs best
feedback_items.your_feedback: This phrase is awkwardly constructed and disrupts the flow of the sentence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase to be more direct: 'in an environment designed to accommodate different learning needs' or similar.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Why do some children seem to struggle with communication or routine, while others formed friendships or grasped language concepts at different paces?
feedback_items.your_feedback: There's a tense inconsistency here - 'seem to struggle' (present) versus 'formed' (past). Keep the tense consistent throughout.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose either all present tense or all past tense for describing your observations.

subject: Law
statement_full_text: [Statement text not fully visible in provided document - appears to be a Law personal statement discussing justice system, human trafficking EPQ, and legal work experience]

feedback_items.your_feedback: Throughout the statement, you're continually mentioning the justice system, inequality, and power dynamics. It's getting repetitive and you need to either provide specific examples or cut some of these references.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Give concrete examples instead of repeatedly stating themes, or cut repetitive mentions entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: from investigating human trafficking in my EPQ
feedback_items.your_feedback: This conclusion paragraph starting with 'from investigating human trafficking in my EPQ' needs to be completely removed. You don't need this at all in the conclusion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the entire conclusion paragraph. Your statement should end before this.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're explaining too much about the skills you have. You don't need to continually explain yourself because you're already doing great in your subjects, you've done an EPQ and an NEA. Let your accomplishments speak for themselves.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove explanations of what skills you gained. Instead, show them through your examples and what you concluded from your experiences.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to include academic sources - some books, some writers you've read. This would strengthen your statement significantly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add references to legal theorists, books, or academic writers that have influenced your thinking about law.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to include your conclusions from the NEA and EPQ. What did you actually find out? What were your key findings?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For both your NEA and EPQ, state what you concluded from the research. This shows your analytical thinking.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need to mention English Language at all. You don't need to mention all of your A-Levels either.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove references to your A-Level subjects unless they directly relate to specific points about law.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall you've done a good job. It's really interesting stuff with really interesting topics. You've done a lot of things as well and it's clear you have strong content to work with.
feedback_items.why_strong: The content and experiences are strong - just needs refinement in presentation.

subject: Politics
statement_full_text: [Statement text not visible in provided document excerpt]

subject: Politics
statement_full_text:
Question 1: Why do you want to study this course or subject? - 1612
My interest in studying politics at university began when I watched a Finacial Times documentary about Brexit. It touched on how many people regretted their vote in the 2016 Referendum because they lacked information about the economic effects of Brexit. This piqued my interest in politics because I wish to understand the mechanisms that allow democracy to work and how a phenomenon like this was able to be. Because this documentary allowed me to understand the importance of being informed about politics, I joined some youth groups which include the Westminster Youth Council, UNA Climate and Oceans, and UNAYP. These groups taught me how to actively engage in youth issues and I seek to use what I learnt to study politics at university.

Question 2: How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
I recently attended a taster course about the resurgence of fascism and I learnt about many thinkers, including Adorno and Reich, and their theories on why fascism is rising in popularity. As a result, I intend for my independent research project in German to be about evaluating the usefulness of Wilhem Reich's ideas to explain the rising popularity of the AfD in Germany. This project will contribute to the scholarly understanding of contemporary political movements while developing critical analytical skills essential for advanced political studies. I found keen interest in Reich's work about the link between fascism and sexual repression so that led me to do some reading into sociologist Foucault's book about the history of sexuality. Foucault's critique conveys the evolving nature of political discourse and highlights the importance of critical analysis. Building on my interest in the factors contributing to fascist movements, my EPQ on Colombian drug cartels also explored the role of many multifaceted factors that resulted in their sustained control over Colombia. Firstly the research element of the project has given me the citation and evaluation skills needed to do well on a politics course. I have also gained insight on how important historical context will be when analysing contemporary politics at university. My research showed that Colombia's history of violence between the liberals and conservatives left the country unstable and drug cartels were able to take advantage of that. This led me to read the book 'Why Nations Fail' as the book was briefly spoken about in my economics class so I knew it would link well to my EPQ.

Question 3: What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
Due to my interest in how poltical ideas manifest in society, I visited the Royal Courts of Justice. One case that stuck out to me was Okpabi et al. v Royal Dutch Shell plc et al. It set important precedent for international corporate liability and it was useful for me to see how some countries have heavy influence over other countries through transnational corporations. This realisation inspired me to take part in Immerse Education's essay competition about how countries use their cultural and economic influence to achieve political goals. This experience taught me about media imperialism, which I found interesting as I do notice how US culture is embedded in almost every level of society, like through film and music.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in studying politics at university began when I watched a Finacial Times documentary about Brexit. It touched on how many people regretted their vote in the 2016 Referendum because they lacked information about the economic effects of Brexit. This piqued my interest in politics because I wish to understand the mechanisms that allow democracy to work and how a phenomenon like this was able to be.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The sentence structure is not the best here. The whole opening paragraph is confusing and wordy. You're using phrases like 'it touched on' and 'this piqued my interest because I wish to understand' which are inefficient.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start more directly: 'I became keen to understand the mechanisms behind democratic systems and the factors that could allow an event like Brexit to occur.' Then introduce the FT documentary as evidence, not as the starting point.

feedback_items.weak_passage: It touched on how many people regretted their vote in the 2016 Referendum because they lacked information about the economic effects of Brexit.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to give more room to expand what you actually mean. What one interesting thing did you take from the documentary? Just bringing in a small amount of detail or supporting evidence shows you watched it and makes the whole thing more concrete.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific examples: 'they lacked information about the economic effects, in particular about how it would affect housing prices or inflation.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: Because this documentary allowed me to understand
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't start sentences with 'because' - it's generally not a good writing technique.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure the sentence to avoid starting with 'because'.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I joined some youth groups which include the Westminster Youth Council, UNA Climate and Oceans, and UNAYP. These groups taught me how to actively engage in youth issues and I seek to use what I learnt to study politics at university.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've got such good content to work with but you don't actually tell me what you did. You mention these great groups but then don't give any specific examples. The conclusion about what you learned is inferred by tutors - it's not for you to say without giving evidence first.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick one of these groups and mention one specific thing you tackled. Say 'one of the particular things we tackled was this issue' and relate it to something relevant. Give detail rather than telling tutors you'll be good at something without evidence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I recently attended a taster course about the resurgence of fascism and I learnt about many thinkers, including Adorno and Reich
feedback_items.your_feedback: The phrase 'I recently attended a taster course' is filler language that doesn't add anything important. Get rid of this type of phrasing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Say directly: 'At a lecture which discussed the resurgence of fascism, with particular emphasis on Adorno and Reich and their belief that fascism is rising in popularity.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I learnt about many thinkers, including Adorno and Reich, and their theories on why fascism is rising in popularity.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is too summary. You need to mention one actual concrete thing - what does Adorno believe? What does Reich believe? Give a bit more proof that you took something from the lecture.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific content: 'Adorno believes this' or 'Reich believes this' with actual details from their theories. Then link it to another school of thought or express whether you agree, or explain how it applies differently in different contexts.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As a result, I intend for my independent research project in German to be about evaluating the usefulness of Wilhem Reich's ideas
feedback_items.your_feedback: Too much filler language. 'As a result, I intend for my independent research project in German to be about' is unnecessarily wordy.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Say directly: 'My independent research project explores William Reich's ideas about the rising popularity of the AfD in Germany.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: This project will contribute to the scholarly understanding of contemporary political movements while developing critical analytical skills essential for advanced political studies.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is another example of something tutors should be thinking, not you telling them. You haven't given enough detail about what you're actually doing with the project - you need to give your conclusion or mention supporting sources.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with actual content: 'During the course of my research, I learned' or 'expect to conclude' or 'one of the most interesting points or factors that came about.' Give specific findings, not claims about skill development.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found keen interest in Reich's work about the link between fascism and sexual repression so that led me to do some reading into sociologist Foucault's book about the history of sexuality.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Too much filler language. 'I found keen interest' and 'so that led me to do some reading into' is unnecessarily wordy.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Say directly: 'Due to my interest in Wright's work, I then came across (or ended up reading) Foucault's [insert actual book title].'

feedback_items.weak_passage: the history of sexuality
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to put the actual title of Foucault's book, not a generic description.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace 'the history of sexuality' with the proper book title.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Foucault's critique conveys the evolving nature of political discourse and highlights the importance of critical analysis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't love that conclusion. It reads too much like a summary and is too general. 'The importance of critical analysis' is important in every book in every subject, so it's not specific enough.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Give a better example or a specific point from the book that relates to your political interests.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Building on my interest in the factors contributing to fascist movements, my EPQ on Colombian drug cartels
feedback_items.your_feedback: All of that introductory stuff makes it really confusing to read. Just go straight into 'I completed an EPQ on Colombian drug cartels, exploring/looking at/researching...'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove 'Building on my interest in the factors contributing to fascist movements' and start directly with your EPQ topic.

feedback_items.weak_passage: also explored the role of many multifaceted factors that resulted in their sustained control over Colombia
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't tell me what the multifaceted factors are. You need to give your main conclusions from the EPQ - that's what's interesting and that's what you've actually done.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: State the specific factors you identified in your research and what you concluded.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Firstly the research element of the project has given me the citation and evaluation skills needed to do well on a politics course.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Get rid of this for similar reasons already explained. You're telling tutors what skills you gained instead of showing them through your work.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence entirely. Let your research findings demonstrate your analytical skills.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have also gained insight on how important historical context will be when analysing contemporary politics at university.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Get rid of this too. Instead, show this insight by applying it: 'In my EPQ I found that with this context, it shows...' and give details of when things actually happened.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with specific application of historical context from your EPQ findings. Show, don't tell.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My research showed that Colombia's history of violence between the liberals and conservatives left the country unstable and drug cartels were able to take advantage of that.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is fine, but it would be even better if you could include some facts and figures or a specific example.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add concrete evidence like dates, statistics, or specific historical events.

feedback_items.weak_passage: as the book was briefly spoken about in my economics class so I knew it would link well to my EPQ
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can't say you read it because it was mentioned in economics class. That's not a good reason and doesn't show intellectual curiosity.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead say why the book 'Why Nations Fail' supported arguments you made in your EPQ, because the writer says [give one conclusion]. That would be good.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This realisation inspired me to take part in Immerse Education's essay competition about how countries use their cultural and economic influence to achieve political goals.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to expand on this essay competition and tell me your conclusion. Don't just mention that you did it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: What did you argue in the essay? What was your main conclusion?

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience taught me about media imperialism, which I found interesting as I do notice how US culture is embedded in almost every level of society, like through film and music.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The last sentence about media imperialism comes out of left field - it just comes out of nowhere. This needs tidying up as it feels random and disconnected.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this idea more fully by connecting it properly to your previous point, or remove it if you can't make a clear connection.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The Royal Courts of Justice visit was actually OK - it worked well up until the essay competition part.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Due to my interest in how poltical ideas manifest in society, I visited the Royal Courts of Justice. One case that stuck out to me was Okpabi et al. v Royal Dutch Shell plc et al. It set important precedent for international corporate liability and it was useful for me to see how some countries have heavy influence over other countries through transnational corporations.
feedback_items.why_strong: This section provides specific detail about what you saw and explains why it was meaningful to your understanding of politics.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You've done a good job overall. You haven't done a bad job, and you've done all the right things in terms of activities and things. It's clear you're interested in the subject.
feedback_items.why_strong: Strong content and activities, just needs improvement in word choice, sentence structure, and which ideas to develop.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You know what's going on - that's very obvious - but you're not applying it to your actual work. You keep explaining skills instead of demonstrating them through specific examples and conclusions.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Throughout the statement, replace explanations of skills with actual applications - show what you learned through specific findings and conclusions.

subject: Unknown
statement_full_text: [Statement text not visible in provided document - appears to be a duplicate entry or separate question response]
